31.name: NSTEMI
31.altText:
High Risk Features:

« Symptoms refractory to medications (e.g. prolonged chest
pain, sustained ventricular tachycardia)

+ Hemodynamic instability

« Elevated cardiac biomarkers

« Persistent ST depression > 0.5mm or new T wave inversion
« Ejection fraction <40%

« Prior angioplasty or CABG

+h/o Diabetes or Chronic Kidney disease


Treatment:
« High risk features > IMMEDIATE coronary catheterization

+ MONA BASCH

« Supplemental oxygen as needed to maintain 02 saturation > 90%

« Aspirin 325 mg chewed

« Nitroglycerin 0.4 mgx 3

+Morphine 2-4 mg

+ B blocker (Metoprolol tartrate 25 mg)

« Statin (Atorvastatin 80 mg)

« Antiplatelet therapy (in addition to aspirin) - Ticagrelor, Prasugrel, Clopidogrel
« Anticoagulant therapy - Heparin, Bivalirudin, Enoxaparin, Fondaparinux

« Thrombolytic therapy is NOT effective in unstable angina or NSTEMI**


Risk Stratification:

« TIMI » all cause mortality

«Age>65

« 3+ risk factors for CAD

« ST depression > 0.5mm

35.name: NIH Stroke Scale
35.altText:
« Level of consciousness W’

« 0=alert; 1 = minor stimulation; 2 = repeated stimulation or pain; 3 = unresponsive
« Ask age and month

« 0=both right; 1 =one right; 2 = both wrong
«Blink eyes and squeeze hands - 0-2
« Horizontal extraocular movements

«0=no nystagmus; 1 = partial nystagmus; 2 = forced nystagmus
«Visual fields
«0=no vision loss; 1 = partial hemianopia; 2 = complete hemianopia; 3 = b/l blind or hemianopia
« Facial palsy » smile
«0=normal; 1= minor; 2 = lower face; 3 = unilateral or bilateral upper and lower face
« Upper extremity motor drift (test both sides)
« 0=no drift; 1 = drift; 2 = hits bed or against gravity; 3 = no effort against gravity; 4 = no movement
« Lower extremity motor drift (test both sides)
« 0= no drift; 1 = drift; 2 = hits bed or against gravity; 3 = no effort against gravity; 4 = no movement

« Limb ataxia - finger-nose and heel-shin
«0=no ataxia; 1=1limb;2=2limbs
« Sensation
«0=normal; 1 = mild-moderate loss; 2 = complete loss or no response

« Extinction - b/l simultaneous stimulation of visual/ tactile/ auditory/ spatial/ personal
«0=normal; 1 =inattention to 1 modality; 2 = profound hemi-inattention or 1+ modality

« Language > name items and describe actions

« 0=normal; 1= mild-moderate; 2 = severe; 3= mute/global aphasia
« Dysarthria - “no if’s and’s or but’s”

«0=normal; 1 =slurring; 2 = unintelligible or mute

*if unable to test > score as 0
* Total scores < 4 - favorable outcomes

36.name: Arterial Blood Gas
36.altText:
Materials:

« Pre-heparinised arterial blood gas syringe and cap
« Arterial blood gas needle (23 gauge)

« Alcohol wipe

« Gauze and tape

Absolute Contraindications:

« Peripheral vascular disease in limb

« Cellulitis surrounding site or arteriovenous fistula
« Abnormal Allen’s test

Relative Contraindications:
« Anti-coagulation therapy, liver disease, low platelets

Procedure:
1. Perform a modified Allen’s test. Check for contraindications.

2. Fully extend and support arm or wrist w/ pillow or blanket

3. Palpate brachial artery or radial artery. Map out course of artery and identify where artery is most
pulsatile.

4. Clean with alcohol wipe. Glove up. Check ABG needle is screwed. Flush through heparin of ABG syringe.
5. Palpate artery w/ non-dominant hand 1 cm proximal to planned puncture site.

6. Hold ABG syringe like a pencil. Insert needle at 45° and slowly advance until flashback. If syringe does not
fill, gently pull back as you may have passed through the back wall. If needed, re-adjust. Do not re-stick.

7. Apply pressure to puncture site, gauze and tape.

8. Remove ABG needle and place cap onto ABG syringe. Invert gently and roll syringe.

41.name: Nasogastric Tube
41.altText:
Materials:

+NG tube

« Lubricant

« Emesis basin and chuck
« Ice chips or water

« Local anesthetic spray

« Large Syringe (Catheter tip)
« pH testing strips
+Flush i

« Tape

Procedure:

1. Position patient sitting upright with head in neutral position
against bed. Lay chuck and emesis basin under patient’s
mouth.

2. Measure tube - tip of nose to ear lobe to epigastrium +5 cm.
Note insertion length.

3. Loosen tube and lube generously. Apply local anesthetic
spray to oropharynx.

4. Advance tube along nasal septum towards occiput. Coach
patient to swallow w/ ice chips or water once gag reflex starts
and tube is in oropharynx. Check that tube is not coiling in
oropharynx.

5. Confirm placement by:
« Inject 10mL of air and listen for “whoosh” at epigastrium
« Aspirate gastric contents and test pH (should be <4)
« Chest X-ray

6. Tape NG tube to nose. Flush with 10mL of water and place
stopper in NG tube port. Attach to low intermittent suction.

(e.g. Aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block)
«Only heard during expiration and split eliminated paradoxically
on inspiration (due to physiologic splitting mechanism)


Wide splitting


« Due to delay in closure of pulmonic valve
« Conditions that delay RV emptying exaggerates normal splitting
(e.g. Pulmonic stenosis, RBBB, Pulmonary HTN)


Fixed splitting b

« Always present (unaffected by respiration)

« Conditions that increase RA and RV blood volume
(e.g. ASD, VSD, LT-RT shunt, RV failure)


PN e
Inspiration:

« louder RT sided murmurs (due to increased venous return) - “Carvallo’s sign”
«e.g. tricuspid or pulmonic valve


Expiration:
« louder LT sided murmurs (due to increased pulmonary return)
« e.g. mitral or aortic valve


Aortic area
(RT upper sternal border)
2nd intercostal space


Pulmonic area
(LT upper sternal border)


Erb’s point: Aortic valve area
(LT sternal border)
*Best for hearing splitting


Tricuspid area
(LT lower sternal border)


Mitral area

(LT midclavicular)
5th intercostal space
Apex of heart

70.name: Congenital Heart Diseases
70.altText:
CONGENITAL HEART DISEASES


CYANOTIC (o7 shunts)


Tetralogy of Fallot:

« Most common cause of early cyanosis


« PROV: Pulmonary stenosis, RT ventricular hypertrophy, Overriding aorta, VSD
« Chest X-RAY = boot-shaped heart


Tricuspid Atresia:
« Requires PFO/ASD +VSD


RT Ventricular Outflow Tract Obstruction: -
«Mild = Pulmonary stenosis, Severe = Tetralogy of Fallot, Very Severe = Hypoplastic RT Heart syndrome


LT Ventricular Outflow Tract Obstruction:
«Mild = Aortic stenosis, Severe = Hypoplastic LT Heart syndrome
« Mitral Atresia = Hypoplastic LT Heart syndrome


Transposition of the Great Arteries:
«Lack of spiraling causes 2 closed circuits (Aorta- RV, Pulmonary artery - LV)
« Chest X-RAY = egg on a string

Truncus Arteriosus:
«Lack of conotruncal ridges forming 2 separate outflow tracts
« Associated with 22q11.2 deletion and hypocalcemia


Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return:
« Abnormal venous drainage
« Chest X-RAY = snowman [=m


ACYANOTIC (7 torrshunts)


Ventricular Septal Defect:
+ Most common CHD
« Interventricular septum fails to fuse
+ Classification:
« Perimembranous, Muscular, Supracristal
- Small lesions (asymptomatic), Large lesions (LT-RT shunt leads to 4 RT heart pressure/failure)

Atrial Septal Defect:
+ Ostium secundum > Ostium primum, 3:1 F:M
+3 areas of septum:
« Ostium secundum (midportion), Ostium primum (lower portion), Sinus venosus (RA & vena cava jxn)
« Small lesions (asymptomatic), Large lesions (LT-RT shunt leads to RA enlargement, 4 RT heart pressure/failure)


AV Canal Defect:

« Strong association with Trisomy 21

« Partial AVCD: severe low ASD or high VSD w/ AV valves present but affected

« Complete AVCD: AV valves not developed and all four chambers contiguous
Patent Ductus Arteriosus:

« Ductus arteriosus fails to close (normally between 12 hours to 3 weeks post birth)


+More common in preterm infants, associated with worsening RDS (respiratory distress syndrome)
+102and v prostaglandins closes ductus arteriosus

Patent Foramen Ovale:

« Septum secundum and primum fail to fuse so valve of foramen ovale fails to close
+Opens during increased RT heart pressure

« Allows paradoxical thrombi (clots enter arterial circulation)

«+ 4 blood flow from pulmonary circulation immediately after birth closes foramen ovale

Coarctation of the Aorta:

« Narrowing of aorta between transverse arch to iliac bifurcation
«Brachial-femoral delay

- Differential cyanosis

+Associated with Turner syndrome

Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension in the Newborn:

« Failure of pulmonary vascular resistance to decrease post birth = continued RT-LT shunting
+May be due to failure of pulmonary vessels to develop fully

Subclavian Sling:

- Dorsal aorta only disappears superiorly
+RT subclavian artery (from 4th aortic arch) passes posterior to trachea/esophagus


Double Aortic Arch:

«+ Dorsal aorta remains intact
+ Compresses esophagus and trachea

71.name: Eisenmenger Syndrome
71.altText:
EISENMENGER SYNDROME

» Chronic left-to-right shunts reverse into right-to-left shunts
~« “Blue kids” instead of “blue babies” b/c reversal takes time


« Chronic left-to-right shunts


«Ventricular septal defect


« Atrial septal defect


« Patent ductus arteriosus


« Increased flow through pulmonary circulation
« Increased pulmonary vascular resistance
« Leads to pulmonary hypertension


« Increase in pulmonary resistance past
resistance of systemic circulation reverses the
shunt (i.e. the shunt is now right-to-left)

-~


Right ventricular hypertrophy
« Due to increased pulmonary pressure


Cyanosis
« Due to deoxygenated blood being
pumped systemically

Polycythemia
« Due to low hemoglobin levels
(decreased oxygen) production of
erythropoietin

Clubbing

« Due to release of local vasodilators in
response to chronic hypoxemia from
failure of platelet precursors to
fragment into platelets


Physical Exam:
« Late central cyanosis
« Digital clubbing

« Polycythemia

72.name: Mitral Valve Prolapse
72.altText:
MITRAL VALVE PROLAPSE

« Prolapse of the mitral leaflets into the left atrium
+ Occurs during mid to late systole


History
« Typically asymptomatic


+ May exhibit:
« Chest pain
«Dyspnea
« Palpitations


Physical Exam


« Midsystolic murmur at the apex with a midsystolic click

« Murmur is louder when left ventricle chamber size is reduced
(eg. Valsalva maneuver or standing)

« Murmur is quieter when left ventricle chamber size is increased
(eg. Squatting or handgrip)


Labs & Diagnostics

« Usually normal chest x-ray

« Usually normal EKG

« “Floppy valve” on ECHO

« Mitral valve regurgitation may occur
depending on severity of mitral valve prolapse


Management
« Asymptomatic patients:


« Exercise
« Healthy diet
+ Reassurance


+ Symptomatic patients:


+ B blockers for chest pain and palpitations

« Increased water and salt intake for orthostatic symptoms
« Catheter or operative valve repair depending on severity
« Do NOT need endocarditis proph

73.name: Ebstein Anomaly
73.altText:
EBSTEIN ANOMALY


« Due to prenatal lithium exposure
« Tricuspid valve is displaced towards apex


«Dilation of RT atrium and “atrialization” (i.e. shrinking) of RT ventricle
« Atrial septal defect
« Tricuspid regurgitation
« Accessory conduction pathways
« Due to close proximity of SA node and right atrium


« e.g. Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
«RT sided heart failure
« Due to tricuspid regurgitation


TRICUSPID ATRESIA
« Atrial septal defect/ Patent foramen ovale + Ventricular septal defect
»Hypoplastic RT ventricle


TOTAL ANOMALOUS PULMONARY VENOUS CONNECTION
« Atrial septal defect
« Dilated RT atrium and ventricle
« Due to increased blood volume from pulmonary veins entering RT atrium

74.name: Persisten Pulmonary Hypertension
74.altText:
PERSISTENT PULMONARY HYPERTENSION

« Normal reduction in pulmonary vascular pressure after birth does not occur


«In utero, pulmonary vascular resistance and pulmonary artery pressure are very high

« Blood is shunted from the right side of the heart to left side of the heart via the foramen
ovale and ductus arteriosus

« Minimal pulmonary blood flow occurs


Normally:


« After birth, breathing room air increases alveolar PO2


«Increase in alveolar PO2 leads to a decrease in pulmonary artery pressure and increase in pulmonary artery flow
« Increase in pulmonary venous return increases pressure of left atrium
+ Closure of the foramen ovale


Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension:

« Lack of reduction in pulmonary vascular resistance leads to cyanosis

« Cause is unknown

+ May be due to failure of pulmonary vessels to develop fully

+ Heart continues to use fetal circulation pathways (RT-LT shunt)

+ Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus remain patent and allow deoxygenated blood
into systemic circulation

75.name: Patent Ductuc Ateriosus
75.altText:
PATENT DUCTUS ARTERIOSUS

« Derived from LT 6th aortic arch
Becomes ligamentum arteriosum after birth (remnant)

Patency maintained by low arterial oxygen content and prostaglandins (e.g. Alprostadil)
« Indomethacin can be used to close patent ductus arteriosus


History:

« Congenital rubella

« Fetal alcohol syndrome

« Associated with congenital coarctation of the aorta

« Can be a lifesaving measure in other congenital heart defects (right to left shunts)
« Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return
« Transposition of the Great Vessels


Before birth
« Right to left shunt before birth to
bypass non-functional lungs


After birth
«Can persist up to 6 weeks after birth
« Left to right shunt if it remains patent


Physical Exam:
+ Often asymptomatic


» Continuous (i.e. spanning systole & diastole) machine like heart murmur
« Heard loudest at S2 and at left infraclavicular area


«Right and Left ventricular hypertrophy

« Cyanosis of lower limbs

«Widened pulse pressure
« Lower diastolic pressure because
some blood in aorta goes through PDA

76.name: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connectoin
76.altText:
TOTAL ANOMALOUS PULMONARY VENOUS CONNECTION

«Right to Left shunt
« All four pulmonary veins fail to connect to left atrium
« Dilated right atrium and ventricle due to increased blood flow from pulmonary veins
. Associated‘\(v’lih an atrial septal defect (ASD) and sometimes patent ductus art_gi__osus (PDA)


History & PE:

« Early respiratory distress
« Cyanosis (e.g. “blue babies”)

« Obstructive TAPVC presents earlier
than Non-obstructive TAPVC


Atrial Septal Defect


Diagnostics & Management:

« ECHO to see abnormally connected
pulmonary veins and ASD or PFO

« Chest X-ray: pulmonary congestion in
obstructive or enlarged RT side of heart and
“snowman”/ “figure-8 sign” in non-obstructive


» Surgery
+ Cardiac catheterization
» Oxygen


Supracardiac TAPVC

« Pulmonary veins drain into an innominate vein,
which enters the superior vena cava


Infracardiac TAPVC

« Pulmonary veins drain into hepatic vein, which
enters inferior vena cava


Cardiac TAPVC
« Pulmonary veins drain into the
coronary sinus, which drains into the
right atrium

77.name: Atrioventricular Canal Defect
77.altText:
ATRIOVENTRICULAR CANAL DEFECT (AVCD)


Normal heart

« Mitral valve separates LT atrium and LT ventricle

« Tricuspid valve separates RT atrium and RT ventricle

« Interatrial septum separates atria and interventricular
septum separates ventricles


Complete AVCD
+Hole at the center of the heart where ventricles
and atria meet
« Forms one large valve between atria and ventricles


« Superior and inferior bridging leaflets
are separated


Partial AVCD

« Defect in atrial septum

« Mitral valve usually abnormal leading to mitral regurgitation
into LT atrium and across opening in AV septum

+ Leads to RT atrial and RT ventricular overload


« Superior and inferior bridging leaflets are
fused

78.name: Tetralogy of Fallot
78.altText:
TETRALOGY OF FALLOT

+ Most common cause of early childhood cyanosis (Right-to-left shunt)
« Anteriosuperior deviation of infundibular septum
« Associated with fetal alcohol syndrome and 22g11 syndromes


History & Physical Exam

« Cyanosis depending on severity and right-to-left shunting across VSD

+Dyspnea

« Tet spells - episodes of hypercyanosis and hypoxemia due to exacerbation of right ventricle outflow (e.g. crying, fever, exercise)

« Squatting to increase systemic vascular resistance and decrease right to left shunting (i.e. more blood from right ventricle goes to lungs)


+ Pulmonic stenosis: systolic ejection murmur in (eft 2nd intercostal space
«Ventricular septal defect: holosystolic murmur at left sternal border


PROV

 Pulmonary stenosis (most important determinant for prognosis)
» Right ventricular hypertrophy due to pulmonary stenosis

» Overriding aorta

. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

» May also have patent ductus arteriosus for survival


Diagnostics & Management

«ECHO
« EKG: right ventricular hypertrophy
« Boot shaped heart on chest X-ray

« Surgery

79.name: Ventricular Septal Defect
79.altText:
VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECT (VSD)

« Abnormal connection between left and right ventricles

«Most common congenital heart lesion

«Is an acyanotic heart lesion (does not interfere w/ amount of oxygen or blood that reaches tissues)

« Usually occurs in membranous portion of interventricular septum due to failure of membranous portion to develop

« Defect results in left-to-right shunting which ultimately increases blood flow to the lungs o g


History

« Infants with smaller VSD may be asymptomatic

« Infants with larger VSD may present with poor feeding and
sweating with feeds due to increased work of breathing i


Physical Exam

« Harsh or blowing holosystolic murmur heard maximally at
left mid to lower sternal border (tricuspid area)

« Larger VSDs has lower intensity murmur than smaller VSDs
« Respiratory abnormalities (e.g. crackles, grunting,
retractions, tachypnea)

« Failure to thrive

«Hepatomegaly


Labs & Diagnostics

« Connection between left and right ventricles on ECHO
«Increased vascular markings on chest x-ray due to pulmonary
edema

« Elevated oxygen saturation in right ventricle and pulmonary artery
on cardiac catherization due to mixing of oxygenated blood from
left ventricle

« Right ventricular hypertrophy on EKG due to increased volume
overload

« May lead to left ventricle overload and heart failure b/c left to
right shunting increases pulmonary blood flow & increases
return to left side of heart


Management
+90% of small VSD’s close spontaneously the first year


« Surgical closure for large VSDs
« Digoxin (digitalis)

« Furosemide (diuretics)

« ACE-inhibitors


« Complications:


« Congestive heart failure
« Endocarditis
« Pulmonary hypertension

80.name: Aneurysm Classification
80.altText:
ANEURYSM CLASSIFICATION

« Weakness in the vessel wall leading to dilation of vessel
« May be congenital or acquired


True Aneurysm

+ Involves all three layers of the vessel wall (Intima, Media, and Adventitia)
+ Attenuated but intact wall


Saccular
« Sac like shape


Fusiform
« Spindle shaped with long tapering ends



False Aneurysm
+ Does not involve all three layers of vessel wall
+ Blood escapes between tunica layers » extravascular hematoma

- Communicates with intravascular space freely


Dissected Aneurysm

« Longitudinal Intima tearing

+ Blood enters between tunica layers

+ Can be located in proximal or distal aorta


Ruptured Aneurysm


Tunica Intima
« Endothelial cells


+Subendothelium w/ scant smooth muscie and extracellular matrix

Tunica Media

« Thickest tunica

« Bound by internal and external lamina

« Contains smooth muscle and elastic lamina w/ extracellular connective tissue matrix
«Vaso vasorum: at media/adventitia border in large vessels

Tunica Adventitia
+ Most external layer


« Contains fibroblasts, connective tissue, and small vessels that
give rise to vaso vasorum

81.name: Coronary Circulation
81.altText:
CORONARY CIRCULATION


+Aorta

« Right Coronary artery (RCA)
« Right Marginal artery (RMA)
« Posterior Descending artery (PDA)

« Left Coronary artery (LCA)
« Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
« Left Circumflex artery (LCX)

85% are RT dominant circulation
+ PDA arises from RCA
8% are LT dominant circulation
+ PDA arises from LCX
7% are codominant circulation

« Posterior wall of ventricles

muscle of left ventricle

+ Anterolateral papillary muscles of left ventricle

« Anterior 2/3 interventricular septum

*LAD is the most commonly occluded = “widowmaker”


« Posterior 1/3 interventricular septum
« Posterior 2/3 walls of ventricles


+ Anterior wall of left ventricle

+ Anterolateral papillary muscles of left ventricle

+ Anterior 2/3 interventricular septum

*LAD is the most commonly occluded = “widowmaker”

82.name: Fetal Venous System
82.altText:
FETAL VENOUS SYSTEM

Embryonic Heart


Sinus venosus


« Fetal venous system drains
into the sinus venosus

« Formed by the union of large
systemic veins

« Passage through which
venous blood enters primitive
heart in fetus


Anterior cardinal veins

Posterior cardinal veins

« Hepatic veins and sinusoids

« Ductus venosus
« Hepatic portal
« Hepatic veins and sinusoids

+Renal veins


Supracardinal veins
Forms:

83.name: Fetal Circulation
83.altText:
FETAL CIRCULATION


*Umbilical Vein —3 Ductus Venosus —3 Inferior Vena Cava —> Right Atrium — Foramen Ovale —3 Left Atrium —» Left Ventricle —» Aorta

* Right Ventricle —> Pulmonary Artery —3 Ductus Arteriosus —» Aortic Arch


Fetal Venous System:
Consists of three main veins:
«Umbilical veins

«Vitelline veins

« Cardinal veins


Cardinal veins
« Return poorly oxygenated blood from the embryo


Anterior cardinal vein


Common cardinal vein


Posterior cardinal vein



Vitelline vein


« Return poorly oxygenated blood from the yolk sac to the embryo’s midgut
« Serves as an early site for the formation of blood
« Derivatives of these veins form the portal venous svstem


Umbilical vein

« Transports oxygenated blood from placenta to infant

«Highest 02 content of the fetal vessels (80% oxygen saturation)
« Low partial pressure of 02 (30% Po2)


Umbilical Artery

« Transports deoxygenated blood

« Branch and form chorionic arteries within chorionic villi of
the placenta (site of nutrient exchange w/ maternal blood)


Umbilical Cord

« Connects infant circulation to placenta
« Consists of:
« Two umbilical arteries
« One umbilical vein
«Arise as branches of the internal iliac arteries


Fetal Shunts:

Ductus Venosus: Shunts oxygenated blood from umbilical vein to inferior
vena cava, bypassing the liver

Ductus Arteriosus: Connects trunk of pulmonary artery to proximal
descending aorta in the fetus, allowing blood from
right ventricle to bypass non-functioning fetal lungs

Foramen Ovale: Directs oxygenated blood from right atrium to left atrium


Allow oxygenated blood flowing from umbilical vein to
bypass fetal liver and lungs

84.name: Sjogren Syndrome
84.altText:
SJOGREN SYNDROME


» Autoimmune destruction of lacrimal & salivary glands
« Focal lymphocytic sialadenitis


« SIGNS & SYMPTOMS:
« Middle aged female
« HLA-DR3 association


« Associated with development of B cell lymphoma (MALT)


« Decreased salivary secretion
« Decreased lacrimal flow

« Interstitial nephritis

« Cholangitis

« Glomerulonephritis


« AUTOANTIBODIES:

« Anti-Ro (SSA)
« Anti-La (SSB)
+ Against ribonucleotides


Dry eyes
“Keratoconjunctivitis sicca”


Parotid enlargement


Dry mouth
“Xerostomia”


Nephritis


Cholangitis


Arthralgias

85.name: Systemic Sclerosis
85.altText:
SYSTEMIC SCLEROSIS

« Fibroblast activation > Collagen deposition » Cutaneous & visceral fibrosis


« SIGNS & SYMPTOMS:

« Middle aged female

« Cutaneous & visceral fibrosis

« Arthralgias

« Microstomia

« Puffy fingers, sclerodactyly

«Raynaud’s phenomenon

« Esophageal dysmotility, LES dysfunction
« Malignant hypertension

«Renal abnormalities


« CREST SYNDROME

» Calcinosis cutis (Ca2+ deposits in skin)
« Raynaud’s phenomenon

« Esophageal dysmotility

« Sclerodactyly

- Telangiectasia

= Limited to face and fingers


Taut “mask”


Myocardial fibrosis


Pulmonary fibrosis
+ Most common cause of death


Gl dysmotility


Muscle fibrosis


« AUTOANTIBODIES:

« Anti-Scl 70 Ab > DNA topoismerase |

« Anti-RNA polymerase Il

« Anti-Centromere Ab (CREST syndrome)

86.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
86.altText:
SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS


« SIGNS & SYMPTOMS:
+Young female
« Fever, fatigue, lymphadenopathy
« Arthralgias


« Malar “buttertly” rash, photosensitivity
« Chest pain, friction rub

« Hematuria/Proteinuria

« Abnormal CBC (-penias)

« Raynaud’s phenomenon

« “RASH OR PAIN” = rash, arthritis, serositis (pericarditis),
hematologic (-penias), oral ulcers, renal issues,

photosensitivity, autoantibodies, immunologic
disorders, neuro (seizures, psychosis)


Fever


Malar Rash


Nephritis


Arthralgias


+ DRUG INDUCED LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS


« Hydralazine
«No renal or CNS involvement
« Anti-Histone Ab


Pericarditis & Pleuritis


« Libman- Sacks Endocarditis
« Vegetations on both sides of
» Mmitral valve


Raynaud’s phenomenon


« DIFFUSE LUPUS NEPHRITIS
« Most common/severe form
« Hematuria/Proteinurea

« Diffuse Proliferative Glomerular Nephritis
« Membranous Glomerular Nephropathy

« Anti-dsDNA Ab > Lupus nephritis
« Anti-Smith Ab > spliceosomal snRNPs
+ Anti-phospholipid Abs
+ Anti-SSA & Anti-SSB
+ Anti-C1q antibodies


« Main causes of death:
+Renal
« Infection
« Cardiovascular

BRACHIAL PLEXUS


MOTOR INNERVATION


TERMINAL BRANCHES

89.name: Menopause
89.altText:
MENOPAUSE

+ 12 months without menstrual periods without any other pathology
« Significant decrease in ovarian estrogen production
« Average onset at 51 years old (if under 40 years old, consider Primary Ovarian Failure)


Pathophysiology:

« ¥ inovarian follicles & = atretic follicles

« Unable to maintain ovulation cycles

 Failure of pleuroperitoneal folds to fuse with septum transversum
«Typically LT sided

+ Hypoplastic ipsilateral lung

« Abnormal budding of ventral foregut endoderm in mediastinum

« Defect in development of terminal bronchioles

+ Resembles cystic lesion or small airways

« Can cause polyhydramnios or hydrops fetalis

+ LLL with own blood supply and abnormal connection to
tracheobronchial tree

«Recurrent pneumonias in SAME location

104.name: Cushing Syndrom
104.altText:
CUSHING SYNDROME


Causes:

#1 = Exogenous Glucocorticoids (latrogenic)

1) ACTH Dependent = Cushing Disease (ACTH secreting Pituitary adenoma)
2) ACTH Independent = Adrenal Lesion (Adrenal Adenoma or Carcinoma)

3) Ectopic ACTH Syndrome = Paraneoplastic Syndrome (ie. Small cell lung carcinoma)

Pathogenesis:

HYPERGLYCEMIA

1. Glucocorticoids decrease glucose utilization: (+) gluconeogenesis, Glycogenolysis,
Proteolysis, Lipolysis

2. Increase blood glucose => Chronic Insulin Secretion

3. Insulin (+) Lipogenesis => Fat redistribution around trunk and excess fat deposits
= Central Obesity, Buffalo Hump, Supraclavicular Fat Pads

= Leads to insulin resistance and drives towards a Type 2 Diabetes state


HYPERTENSION
1. Glucocorticoids have some mineralocorticoid activity

=increase Na+ & H20 retention

2. Glucocorticoids increase cardiovascular sensitivity to
catecholamines and increase Ang Il effects
=Vasoconstriction

= Leads to Hypertension

RECURRENT INFECTIONS
1. Glucocorticoids are immune suppressing
=Recurrent infections, Impaired Wound healing

OSTEOPOROSIS
1. Glucocorticoids increase bone resorption
= Osteoporosis


STRIAE
1. Glucocorticoids increase catabolism of collagen in SQ tissues
= Striae, Bruising, Skin thinning

MUSCLE WEAKNESS
1. Glucocorticoids increase catabolism of muscle (proteolysis)
=Muscle Weakness, thin arms and legs


HIRSUTISM

1. ACTH stimulates zona reticularis = Androgen production

2. Women are more affected b/c adrenals is main place for androgen
production while men also have testses for androgen production

= Hirsutism, Oligomenorrhea

NEUTROPHILS
1. Glucocorticoids increase circulating WBC and increase

demargination of neutrophils from endothelial surface
= Increased WBC (*Neutrophils)


Complications:

-Recurrent Infections
-Hypertension
-Diabetes Mellitus
-Osteoporosis
-Oligomenorrhea

115.name: OX PHOS

OX PHOS

NADH & FADH2 (from glycolysis and TCA) are oxidized back to NAD+ and FAD+


Complex|

1) NADH dehydrogenase converts NADH to NAD

2) e-is pumped through iron cluster to Coenzyme Q (ubiquinone)
**Produces free radicals

Complex Il

1) Succinate dehydrogenase converts FADH2 to FAD using CoQ
2) e- are added to the CoQ pool


Complex il
1) Shuttles e- to cytochrome ¢ (mobile e- carrier)

Cytochrome B complex can form superoxide and Cytochrome C can form H202
**Produces free radicals

Complex IV

1) Cytochrome c brings e- to to cytochrome ¢ oxidase
2) Final e- acceptor = oxygen and is reduced to H20
ComplexV

1) Shuttle of electrons allows H+ to be pumped to inter membrane space = creating electrochemical gradient
2) H+ flows back down gradient through Complex V and ATP synthase makes ATP

**Thermogenin (Dinitrophenol) = OXPHOS uncoupler


CoQ:
+ Membrane bound receptor that shuttles e- between Complex I, I &Il
+ Becomes fully reduced to Hydroquinone if accepts 2 e-

+ Becomes reduced to Semiquinone if accepts 1 e- (free radical)

ADULT BRAIN TUMORS

 IDH mutant has better prognosis - P53 mutation

» MICRO: Pseudo-palisading cells are viable cells
along edges of necrotic area

+1°sporadic 5 NF2 mutation

127.name: Sleep
127.altText:
SLEEP


Suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN)
1. Neurons of retina


2. SCN synchronizes circadian rhythm of sleep-wake cycle to light-dark cycles


3. Posterior and lateral hypothalamus INITIATES sleep and its function is synced to circadian rhythm


Sleep promoting:


«Ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO)
1.GABAergic neurons in VLPO inhibit neurons of ascending activating pathways


« Melatonin
1. Onset of darkness
2. SNS activation of pineal gland


3. Releases norepinephrine to activate enzymes that convert serotonin to melatonin
4. Melatonin diffuses out into blood stream
5. Melatonin acts at SCN to dampen wake-promoting signal and promote sleep


+Adenosine

1. Adenosine levels accumulate during the day > reaches a threshold concentration
2. Inhibits activity of wake-promoting CNS regions
3. Activates VLPO > promotes sleep


« Cytokines
« Prostaglandin D2


« Growth hormone releasing hormone

« Medullary reticular formation and Nucleus solitarius

+ Sleep promoting regions in medulla


Switch between REM and NREM sleep

« Pontine reticular formation = contains REM-off and REM-on cells

REM-ON cells: REM-OFF cells:

+ Acetylcholine +Norepinephrine
+Dopamine +Serotonin
- Glutamate  Histamine

«Orexin


Wake promoting:

« Ascending reticular activating system (ARAS)

+ Projects to thalamus and cerebral cortex
+ Results in cerebral cortical activation during wakefulness


Neuromodulation
«Norepinephrine
+Serotonin

« Histamine

- Orexin

« Acetylcholine

- Dopamine

«Glutamate


1. During wakefulness, all neurotransmitters are ON

2. During NREM sleep all neurotransmitters are inhibited by GABAergic neurons in VLPO
(since they promote wakefulness)

3. During REM, REM-ON cells and VLPO further inhibit Norepinephrine and Serotonin so
REM-ON cells can increase activity in brainstem for REM sleep.

4. Acetylcholine neurons in brainstem project to thalamus and cortex » activating changes
of REM sleep seen on EEG that resembles awake state

5. Brainstem acetylcholine neurons activate Ponto-Geniculate-Occipital (PGO) pathway >
induces dream imagery and REM

Why don’t we move our limbs during REM sleep if our motor
cortex is active?

+ Glutaminergic REM-ON cells in pontine reticular formation activate inhibitory
Glycine in medulla and spinal cord to inhibit lower motor neuron activity

+ This decreases muscle tone

+ Eye movement is not inhibited by this circuit > REM = “rapid eye movement”

128.name: Migraine Headaches
128.altText:
MIGRAINE HEADACHES

« Disturbance of cortical, brainstem and hypothalamic excitability


MIGRAINE PATIENTS

« Hyperexcitable brainstem and hypothalamus
+ Results in abnormal activity of raphe nuclei, locus ceruleus, and periaqueductal gray area
+ These areas fire without a pain signal
+ Leads to associated migraine symptoms: Photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, vomiting, and allodynia
«Hypersensitivity to dopamine and serotonin
« Low baseline serotonin




« Posterior hypothalamus INITIATES migraine
+ 2 blood flow to hypothalamus, periaqueductal gray
area, locus ceruleus, and ventral tegmental area
+ Input ascends to Trigeminal cervical center
+ Hypothalamus regulates symptoms:

+Mood changes

« Fatigue

« Irritability

+ Food cravings

« Stiff neck

« Phonophobia


AURA


« Cortical Spreading Depression > Aberrant firing of neurons:
+ Wave of hyperexcitability that spreads through cortex
« Followed by prolonged widespread neuronal inhibition
+ Linked to initiation of headache phase and activation of
trigeminal system


HEADACHE


« Activation of nociceptive nerves of Trigeminal cervical
center (contains trigeminal nerve and cervical nerves)
« Nerve fibers project to leptomeningies, dural vessels,


and cerebral arteries
« Results in pain of headache


POSTDROME


Trigemino-vascular response


«Activation of trigeminal pain pathway

+Releases Substance P and CGRP

+Results in neurogenic inflammation of pain sensitive meninges and
dilation of cranial vessels

+Also feedbacks to prolong pain experience resulting in central
sensitization (maintenance and development of chronic pain)


Trigemino-autonomic reflex

« Trigeminal cervical center activates Superior salivatory nucleus

« Superior salivatory nucleus drives parasympathetic vasodilator pathway

« Hypothalamus modulates descending inhibitory pain pathways through its
connections to superior salivatory nucleus, periaqueductal gray area, locus
ceruleus, raphe nuclei, and trigeminal complex

PFK-2 Regulation of Glycolysis and Gluconeogenesis:


1. Liver requires citrate to make FA in gluconeogenesis
2. But + citrate and ATP negatively feedback to PFK-1 = inhibits glycolysis

3. Fructose-6-phosphate accumulates and is shunted to Fructose 2,6- phosphate by PFK-2

= provides liver with citrate for FA synthesis

1. Diagnostic stage: cysts and trophozoites in stool
2. Infective stage: ingestion of mature cysts

3. Excystation in small intestine and trophozoites are
released and go to large intestine

4. Trophozoites disrupt host cell membrane by
producing amebapores and invade intestinal epithelium

cause dysentery

“Invasion into portal venous system

Forms free radical metabolites and damages DNA


Incidence in South and Central America, Mexico, India, SE Asia
Transmission: ingestion of fruit and vegetables contaminated with
sporulated oocyst

2. Oocysts sporulate in environment

_stomach cramps, fatigue, nausea, low fever, weight loss

Transmission: ingestion of food/water contaminated w/
sporulated oocyst

9) ZYGOTES invade midgut wall of mosquito and develop into 0OCYSTS
